training_organizations.name: Washington State Alliance for Child Welfare Excellence
training_organizations.description: A partnership involving Washington’s Department of Children, Youth, and Families (DCYF), University of Washington, Eastern Washington University, and others to deliver training statewide. The Alliance develops and conducts all pre-service training for new CPS workers and licensors, as well as ongoing in-service courses. It also trains caregivers (foster parents and relative caregivers). By leveraging university expertise, the Alliance ensures Washington’s child welfare workforce and caregivers have access to comprehensive, research-based training and support.

training_organizations.name: Olive Crest (Washington)
training_organizations.description: A nonprofit agency that partners with Washington DCYF to recruit and support foster families, particularly for hard-to-place children (like large sibling groups or children with therapeutic needs). Olive Crest manages certain foster homes and provides the families with training and caseworker support, under contract with the state:contentReference[oaicite:51]{index=51}. It also runs some preventive programs (to stabilize families and prevent foster placements). Utilizing Olive Crest helps Washington expand its foster home capacity and find nurturing placements for children who might otherwise stay in shelters or far from their community.

training_organizations.name: Casey Family Programs
training_organizations.description: A national operating foundation headquartered in Seattle that works closely with Washington’s child welfare system. Casey Family Programs provides strategic consulting and technical assistance to DCYF and local courts, often piloting innovative approaches in Washington to safely reduce the number of children in foster care. They also directly serve some youth in care through their own foster care program (historically, Casey took long-term foster care cases in WA). Casey’s partnership with Washington includes funding or supporting prevention initiatives, helping improve extended foster care services, and advising on child welfare policy changes – leveraging private foundation resources to improve public system outcomes.

policies.TribalFoster: Yes, Tribes within state provide foster care
policies.TribalScreen: Yes, Tribes directly conduct screening and collaborate with state/local public child welfare agency
policies.DecentralScreen: During certain times of the day, counties/regions have own screening unit
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Def_Subtype_Abuse: Abuse includes physical abuse, punishment, sexual abuse, and sex trafficking; Physical abuse includes shaken baby syndrome
policies.Def_Subtype_Neglect: Neglect includes abandonment, emotional maltreatment, inadequate clothing, inadequate shelter, malnourishment, medical neglect, parent responsibilities, and failure to protect
policies.EquityStaff_Specify: Office of Racial Equity and Social Justice
policies.NearFatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.TribalFoster_Specify: Chehalis Confederated Tribes; Colville Confederated Tribes; Lummi Nation; Muckleshoot Tribe; Port Gamble S'Klallam Tribe; Puyallup Tribe; Quinault Nation; Shoalwater Bay Tribe; Snoqualmie Tribe; Spokane Tribe; Tulalip Tribes; Yakama Nation Confederated Tribes
policies.TribalScreen_Specify: Kalispel Tribe; Makah Tribe; Nisqually Tribe; Port Gamble S'Klallam Tribe; Shoalwater Bay Tribe; Suquamish Tribe; Tulalip Tribes conduct screening. Snoqualmie Tribe collaborates with state agency during screening process
policies.Reporter_OtherSpecify: Licensed pathologists; Staff or volunteers in the Family and Children's Ombudsman Office; Any adult who resides with a child suspected to have suffered severe abuse
policies.DecentralizedReporting: During some times of the day, counties/regions have own reporting hotline
policies.InvestReq_OtherSpecify: If a child is believed to be unsafe and the child's whereabouts out-of-state are known, make a Child Protective Services (CPS) report in that state; If the investigation involves a military parent or guardian, notify the Department of Defense Family Advocacy Program, per the military Memorandum of Understanding; Provide infant safety education and intervention for all children in the household age birth to one year; Conduct a universal domestic violence (DV) screening; Complete the Investigative Assessment (IA); Refer a child or youth with complex behavioral health needs for a Wraparound Intensive Services (WISe) screen; Make a referral to Early Support for Infants and Toddlers (ESIT) services if a child younger than three years old is identified with a possible developmental delay; Conduct monthly health and safety visits with children and youth and monthly visits with parents or guardians when cases are open longer than 60 calendar days
policies.EquityStaff_OtherSpecify: Provide the vision, expertise, and accountability mechanisms necessary to make progress on DCYF's commitment to advance racial equity and to reduce the impact of racial and ethnic disproportionality and disparities
policies.DefPerp_VaryByTypeSpecify: For negligent treatment or maltreatment, the perpetrator is a child's parent, legal custodian, guardian, or caregiver; For abandonment, the perpetrator is a parent or guardian
policies.InvestQual_TrainingSpecify: Child Abuse Interviewing & Assessment training for physical and sexual abuse case investigations; Initial Core training for investigations with a specialized track or FAR
policies.AltResp_Inelig_OtherSpecify: Severe maltreatment or abuse by a parent or caregiver; Injury to non-mobile infant; Allegation of commercial sexual exploitation; Child-on-child sexualized contact; Medical abuse reported on behalf of medical professional
policies.InvestQual_ExperienceSpecify: Social Services Specialist 3: 3 years with a bachelor's degree; 2 years of paid social service experience with a master's degree; Social Services Specialist 2: 1 year as a Social Services Specialist 1 and completion of Social Service Specialist training program with bachelor's degree; 1 year of paid social service experience with master's degree; No experience required for Social Services Specialist 1
policies.InvestReq_OtherCases_Specify: These activities are generally case-specific as noted in the descriptions; however, conducting a universal domestic violence (DV) screening and completing the Investigative Assessment (IA) are required for all reports
policies.ReporterPenalty_OtherSpecify: Licensed pathologists; Staff or volunteers in the Family and Children's Ombudsman Office; Any adult who resides with a child suspected to have suffered severe abuse
policies.ScreenerQual_TrainingSpecify: Unspecified trainings at start of employment and Next Steps for Staff training between 6-12 months of employment
policies.DefMal_Harm_VaryByTypeSpecify: Sexual abuse and sex trafficking definitions include inflicts harm only
policies.CaseManagerQual_ExperienceSpec: Social Services Specialist 3: 3 years with a bachelor's degree; 2 years of paid social service experience with a master's degree; Social Services Specialist 2: 1 year as a Social Services Specialist 1 and completion of Social Service Specialist training program with bachelor's degree; 1 year of paid social service experience with master's degree; No experience required for Social Services Specialist 1
policies.InvestReq_MedEvalCases_Specify: If indicators of serious child abuse or neglect exist; If a child is 3 or younger with a physical abuse allegation; If the alleged child abuse and neglect cannot be reasonably attributed to the explanation and a diagnostic finding would clarify the assessment of risk or determine the need for medical treatment; If the alleged neglect includes concerns that children are deprived of food, underweight, or are starved; Consultation with the Child Protection Medical Consultation Network (CP Med-Con) or with a Child Advocacy Center (CAC) physician is required to (1) determine if a child alleged to be sexually abused needs a medical examination, (2) when there is an allegation of sexual abuse that includes physical injury to the child or the potential for the child to have a sexually transmitted disease, (3) when the child is seriously injured, and (4) when there is a pattern of injury to a young child because of alleged child abuse or neglect
policies.ScreenerQual_ExperienceSpecify: Social Services Specialist 3: 3 years with a bachelor's degree; 2 years of paid social service experience with a master's degree; Social Services Specialist 2: 1 year as a Social Services Specialist 1 and completion of Social Service Specialist training program with bachelor's degree; 1 year pf paid social services experience with master's degree; No experience required for Social Services Specialist 1
policies.AltResp_EligibilityMaltreatment: Only certain types of maltreatment are eligible
policies.ExtFosterCare_Reentry_OtherSpec: Meet extended foster care eligibility criteria
policies.AltResp_Eligibility_OtherSpecify: Does not have previous shelter care or dependency in the home closed in the last 12 months; Is not alleged victim already in out-of-home care
policies.InvestReq_HomeStudyCases_Specify: Issues that may pose a child safety threat or risk of imminent harm, e.g., housing inspector, health department or other local authority
